text: Within this executive team, sensitive issues and bad news are shared promptly and candidly.
I believe my peers on this team consistently act in the best interests of the enterprise, even when it conflicts with their functional agenda.
I am comfortable admitting to this team when I have made a mistake or misjudgment.
I trust my colleagues on this team to follow through on commitments made in our meetings.
Decisions we make as an executive team are transparent in rationale to each other, even when we disagree.
We speak with one voice after decisions are made, regardless of prior debate in the room.
I believe others on this team would actively support me if I faced a major setback or external challenge.
I feel safe raising ethical or reputational concerns, even if they slow down attractive opportunities.
In this team, we take time to understand each other’s functional and personal constraints before pushing for decisions.
My peers show genuine interest in my pressures (board, investors, regulators, markets) rather than dismissing them as excuses.
When conflict arises, we work to understand underlying concerns rather than treating it as a win–lose argument.
As a team, we consider the human impact on employees and customers when making major strategic or cost decisions.
Members of this team are willing to flex timelines or expectations when a colleague is managing a critical personal or health issue.
We actively seek to understand how our decisions land on middle managers and frontline teams before finalizing them.
I feel I can surface concerns about my own wellbeing or sustainability in this role without being perceived as weak or less committed.
We role-model listening and empathy in our behavior, knowing it sets the tone for the rest of the organization.
As an executive team, we have a shared, specific, and current view of our enterprise strategy and “what winning looks like” over the next 3–5 years.
We are aligned on the few critical priorities that must be delivered in the next 12–24 months, and we use them to guide trade-offs.
Our individual functional or business-unit goals are explicitly linked to agreed enterprise priorities.
In this team, we make decisions primarily from an enterprise perspective, not based on functional turf or politics.
We provide the organization with consistent messages about strategy, priorities, and performance, even when decisions are tough.
Our resource allocation (capital, talent, time) matches our stated strategic priorities.
We have clear, agreed decision rights and governance (who decides what, how, and when) for major enterprise choices.
We regularly review and adjust priorities together in response to external shifts, rather than each reacting in silos.
We visibly close the loop with the organization on big decisions (what we decided, why, and what it means for people).
As an executive team, we share a compelling, coherent story of why our organization exists and the impact it aims to have.
I personally feel a strong sense of purpose in the work we do as an executive team, beyond financial outcomes.
Our discussions regularly connect strategic decisions back to our stated mission and values.
We explicitly consider long-term value creation (customers, employees, communities, environment) in our strategic trade-offs.
We ensure that our purpose and values are reflected in how we handle crises and dilemmas, not just in normal times.
I believe our people across levels would recognize the same core purpose we describe in this room.
My work on this executive team aligns with my personal values and sense of contribution.
We actively steward the culture of the organization, not just the financial and operational results.
In this executive team, I can raise dissenting views or challenge assumptions without fear of negative career consequences.
We can admit when we do not know something or need help, without losing credibility in the group.
When someone raises a risk, concern, or “inconvenient truth,” we respond with curiosity and problem-solving, not defensiveness.
Robust, even heated, debate is welcomed as long as it is in service of the enterprise and handled respectfully.
We surface and learn from failed initiatives openly at this level, rather than burying or spinning them.
I feel safe naming issues in our own effectiveness as an executive team (e.g., dynamics, decision-making, capability gaps).
We make it explicitly okay for our direct reports to bring problems and half-baked ideas to us without fear.
The way we behave in this room makes it easier for teams below us to speak up, experiment, and report issues.
